page.title: 01General Land View Silverdale
page.content: This Eastern verge of Morecambe Bay covers a small area of coastline within the boundary of Silverdale village. It is within a Designated Area Of Outstanding Natural Beauty. It is sparsely populated in three small groups of houses and cottages. There is a small amount of farmland used for grazing and a disused quarry now used as a sheep run with long feeding troughs. These are used twice monthly when the high tides deprive the sheep of grazing on the salt marshes. The coastline varies from a gentle slope on the Eastern side to steeply sloping cliffs of broken rock up to 15 metres high. On the Western side of the peninsula is a break in the cliffs called The Cows Mouth which was used by drovers bringing cattle across the Kent Estuary.
